- Click on the camera or microphone button - just make sure you only have one device connected for each.

But what I actually saw was that the "remember this decision" string is a few pixels more to the right compared to the device name string.

Interestingly, if you disable Proton (just toggle `browser.proton.enabled`), the alignment issue still exists, but it's not as noticeable - see attached image "proton off". And I noticed that even with `browser.proton.doorhangers.enabled` set to true, the issue persists. This bug is actually reproducible for all WebRTC permission panels when only strings are displayed (one device of each type).

the memory usage of the gpu thread will rapidly and acceleratingly increase in size, potentially to the point where the user's machine will hang.
in my tests it levels out around 9,5gb of used memory (which was when the memory usage on my system reached 100%). i also managed to hang the system once when another application started digging into the already empty memory.

occasionally the gc will come in and clear memory, but it will not do this enough to prevent firefox from accumulating ram.


expected results:

the memory should not increase at such a rapid rate. and the application should not crash the system

My setup: I'm using a NVIDIA RTX 2080 GPU, and my user agent is Mozilla/5.0. Here's how to reproduce the issue:

First, make sure GPU acceleration is turned on. Then, follow these steps: open index.html in a new tab, click the "Click me!" button, and observe Firefox's memory usage increasing rapidly (we're talking GBs here!). If you let it go unchecked, your system might even hang due to low memory availability.

In my tests, I saw the GPU thread memory usage shoot up to around 9.5GB before leveling off (which was when my system memory reached 100%). And if another app starts using up available memory? Forget about it - the whole system will crash! It's like Firefox just keeps accumulating RAM without stopping.

Now, occasionally the garbage collector (GC) does kick in and clear out some memory, but even that isn't enough to prevent Firefox from hogging all the RAM. My expectation is that the memory shouldn't increase so wildly, and the app should be able to run without crashing the system."

text:
created attachment 9223917
spoof.bundle.html

after set `reportvalidity()` as `canvas.toblob` callback and set `contenteditable` to `true`, the [reportvalidity validationmessage](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/docs/web/api/htmlselectelement/setcustomvalidity) will persist even the tab was closed. as the [validationmessage](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/docs/web/api/htmlselectelement/setcustomvalidity) is persist on the screen, after the tab was closed the validationmessage still show to previous active tab.

in this report i demonstrate i able to spoof validationmessage on twitter then overlap the twitter button intent (which press enter also works) to retweet/like the tweet. 

as the validationmessage is showed on secure domain, user will likely trust the message is from the website, and the validationmessage will overlap twitter button intent message so user won't notice that press enter will retweet/like the tweet.

mozregression show it is regression of [bug 1684792, open form validation popup anchored at screen coordinate as datetime picker and select do so that it is positioned correctly in out of process iframes](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1684792)

## affected version:
- firefox nightly 90.0a1 (2021-05-27) (64-bit)
- firefox release 88.0.1 (64-bit)

## unaffected version:
- firefox 78.10.1esr (64-bit)

## steps to reproduce:
1. visit attached spoof.bundle.html
2. click "spoof validationmessage" button
3. validation message appear on twitter website
4. if you're logged in then press enter to like the tweet

NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

I ran into an issue where if I set the `reportvalidity()` function as a callback for the `canvas.toblob` property and also enabled `contenteditable`, the validation message would persist even after I closed the tab. And to make things worse, this message would still be visible on the previous active tab, like it was stuck there or something! 

It gets even more interesting - using this bug, I managed to spoof a validation message on Twitter, which then overlapped with their own button intent (like when you press enter to retweet or like something). And because this message looks like it's coming from the website, users are likely to trust it and won't notice that pressing enter is actually going to retweet or like the tweet. 

By the way, it seems that this bug is a regression of an older issue (#1684792) where form validation popups would be anchored at screen coordinates in out-of-process iframes.

Here are some details on what I experienced:

* Affected versions:
  - Firefox Nightly 90.0a1 (2021-05-27), 64-bit
  - Firefox Release 88.0.1, 64-bit

* Unaffected version: 
  - Firefox ESR 78.10.1, 64-bit

Here's the rewritten bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

Hey, I'm reporting an issue where when I click the "customize in settings" button from the onboarding modal in Firefox, instead of being taken to the already opened "about:preferences" page with the search pane (or privacy pane after Bug 1730580 lands), I get redirected to the sync pane. This happens regardless of whether I'm using Firefox Beta 93.0b4 or Nightly 94.0a1 on Windows 10 x64, macOS 10.15.7, or Linux Ubuntu 20.04 x64. 

To reproduce this issue, I have session restore enabled and the "about:preferences" page opened with something other than search pane displayed (e.g., sync). Then, I set up some specific preferences like `browser.urlbar.quicksuggest.enabled` to true, `browser.urlbar.quicksuggest.scenario` to online, and so on. After restarting the browser, I click the "customize in settings" button from the onboarding modal and observe the behavior.

As you'd expect, when this happens, I should be taken back to the already opened "about:preferences" page with the search pane (or privacy pane after Bug 1730580 lands) in focus. But instead, I'm stuck with the sync pane. 

I've also noticed some errors popping up in the browser console when I click that button - something about a lazy browser being prematurely inserted via loaduri property access. And there's an error message saying "TypeError: Can't access property 'gotopref', browser.contentwindow is null" (in Nightly) or simply "TypeError: browser.contentwindow is null" (in Beta). 

I've attached a screen recording of the issue, so you can see exactly what I'm talking about.

text:
user agent: mozilla/5.0 (macintosh; intel mac os x 10_15_7) applewebkit/537.36 (khtml, like gecko) chrome/101.0.4951.64 safari/537.36

steps to reproduce:

starting with firefox 101, i noticed that a launched window's initial tab does not appear to be registered as an available target and does not get returned by `target.gettargets`. this only appears to be a problem in windows, with my repro environment being on windows 10.

to reproduce:

1. start firefox 101 with remote debugging enabled:

`start 'c:\program files (x86)\mozilla firefox\firefox.exe' 'about:blank', '--remote-debugging-port=51959'`

2. connect to launched instance and issue `target.gettargets` message (simple script provided here: https://gist.github.com/tbiethman/9add1e991efbecdbe3e6eddec9fb4b46)


actual results:

with firefox 101, the `target.gettargets` message resolves with no found targets, with script output:

```
found targets
{ targetinfos: [] }
```


expected results:

the initial tab target should be returned, with the script output looking something like:

```
found targets
{
  targetinfos: [{
    targetid: 'xxxxxxx-xxxxxx-xxxxxxx',
    type: 'page',
    title: '',
    url: 'about:blank',
    attached: false,
    browsercontextid: null,
  }]
}
```
this is what returns when running the repro steps against firefox 100 in windows. this is also the behavior exhibited by the macos version of firefox 101, with the initial tab target returning as expected.

----

a data couple points that might be relevant:

* with firefox 101, if i spawn another window (with ctrl+n) from the initial window, the script will start returning targets upon subsequent executions.
* also with firefox 101, if i spawn the initial window in troubleshooting mode (with the `-safe-mode` option), the tab does return as a target for the initial window.
* i thought that this may be due to differences in handling of 'about:blank' in v101, but launching to an actual location (say, 'https://www.mozilla.org') still results in no targets being returned.

if i can provide can other data points that could be helpful, or if i've missed something completely in the protocol and this behavior is now expected, please let me know.
user_behviou:
Here's the assessment:

Grammar: Good
Steps to Reproduce (S2R): Good
Expected Result (ER): Best
Actual Result (AR): Best
Additional Information: Good
NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

"I'm reporting an issue with Firefox 101 on Windows 10. When I launch a new window using remote debugging, the initial tab doesn't seem to register as a target and isn't returned by `target.gettargets`. This is only happening on Windows - my repro environment is set up with Windows 10 and Firefox 101.

To reproduce this issue, follow these steps:

1. Start Firefox 101 with remote debugging enabled using the command: `start 'c:\program files (x86)\mozilla firefox\firefox.exe' 'about:blank', '--remote-debugging-port=51959'`.
2. Connect to the launched instance and run a simple script that issues the `target.gettargets` message (check out this gist for the script: https://gist.github.com/tbiethman/9add1e991efbecdbe3e6eddec9fb4b46).

What happens instead is that the `target.gettargets` message resolves with no found targets. The output looks like this:

```
found targets
{ targetinfos: [] }
```

But what I expect to see is the initial tab target returned, with an output like:

```
found targets
{
  targetinfos: [{
    targetid: 'xxxxxxx-xxxxxx-xxxxxxx',
    type: 'page',
    title: '',
    url: 'about:blank',
    attached: false,
    browsercontextid: null,
  }]
}
```

This is what happens when I run the same steps against Firefox 100, and also on the Mac version of Firefox 101 - the initial tab target returns as expected.

A couple more data points that might be relevant:

* If I spawn another window from the initial one (using Ctrl+N), the script starts returning targets after subsequent executions.
* If I launch the initial window in troubleshooting mode (-safe-mode option), the tab does return as a target for the initial window.
* I thought maybe this was related to how Firefox 101 handles 'about:blank', but launching to an actual location (like https://www.mozilla.org) still results in no targets being returned.

If there's anything else you'd like me to provide or if you think this behavior is now expected, please let me know!"

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

I'm seeing an issue where the "Edit This Site" button in Firefox gets stuck in a selected state when you click on it from the top sites section and then hit the Esc key. This happens on multiple versions of Firefox, including 95.0a1, 94.0, 93.0, 91.2.0esr, and 78.15.0esr, as well as on Windows 10 x64, macOS 10.15, and Ubuntu 21.04.

When I follow the steps to reproduce the issue - which is simply opening Firefox, clicking on the "Edit This Site" button from the top sites section, and then hitting Esc - what actually happens is that the button remains selected instead of disappearing like it's supposed to when you're not hovering over it. This isn't a new problem, by the way - I've been able to reproduce this same behavior all the way back in Firefox 69.0a1 from May 2019, so it doesn't seem like this is a regression or anything.

I've attached a screen recording that shows what's going on if you want to take a look for yourself. Interestingly, I've also found that if you drag the "Edit This Site" button (or even the "Open Menu" button) around, you can reproduce this same issue - so it might be worth looking into why these two buttons are behaving in a similar way.

text:
**steps to reproduce:**
1. update firefox to at least version 88.0 stable.
2. launch firefox.
3. join any zoom meeting using their web client. it doesn't matter whether it is a meeting with only 2 participants (me and someone else) or with more (20 for example).
4. listen to the speaker and hear what is described in the "actual results" section.

**actual results:**
the audio on zoom has strange tearing artifacts, which often make it really hard to understand what the speaker is talking about if they don't speak slow enough.

this issue occurs on my 2 completely different pcs so i don't think it may be hardware specific.

**expected results:**
the audio should be clear, without these artifacts, as it used to be.

**regression range:**
thanks to mozregression, i was able to narrow it down to 3 changesets that landed at once at the same time.

the last good one: [2705f924b635eb7a999e7b407c2beaedc584c175](https://hg.mozilla.org/integration/autoland/rev/2705f924b635eb7a999e7b407c2beaedc584c175)
the first bad one: [e08e703105231b0e270996dac0e0359db757644f](https://hg.mozilla.org/integration/autoland/rev/e08e703105231b0e270996dac0e0359db757644f)
user_behviou:
**Best**

The report meets all the criteria:

1. Steps to Reproduce (S2R) are provided.
2. Expected Result (ER) is clearly stated.
3. Actual Result (AR) describes the issue.
4. Additional Information includes software version, regression range, and a clear indication of hardware non-specificity.

No code or logs are present, as requested.
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report in a conversational tone:

So, I've got this weird issue with Zoom audio on Firefox. Here's what happens: I updated my Firefox to at least version 88.0, launched it, joined any old Zoom meeting (doesn't matter if it's just me and someone else or a bigger group), and started listening to the speaker. But then, I notice that the audio gets all wonky with these strange tearing artifacts - it's like there are patches of nothingness in the sound. If the person speaking isn't talking super slow, it's basically impossible to understand what they're saying! I've tried this on two different PCs, and both have the same issue, so I don't think it's a hardware thing. What I'm expecting is clear audio without these artifacts, like it used to be. But since version 88.0, things have gone awry. I managed to narrow down the problem using Mozregression to three changesets that landed at once - the last good one was [2705f924b635eb7a999e7b407c2beaedc584c175](https://hg.mozilla.org/integration/autoland/rev/2705f924b635eb7a999e7b407c2beaedc584c175) and the first bad one was [e08e703105231b0e270996dac0e0359db757644f](https://hg.mozilla.org/integration/autoland/rev/e08e703105231b0e270996dac0e0359db757644f).

steps to reproduce:

open a website and click on a link which tries to download a file.


actual results:

error message with " could not be saved, because an unknown error occurred. try saving to a different location." appears, see attached screenshot "download-not-working.png"


expected results:

ask if i want to save or open the download.

i tested this problem with mozregression, and it said that it was caused by https://phabricator.services.mozilla.com/d129398 and indeed, if i disable "browser.download.improvements_to_download_panel", it's working again as before, so it's related to that setting now being enabled by default.

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

I'm running into a weird issue where when I try to download a file from a website, instead of getting prompted to save or open it like usual, I get an error message saying "could not be saved, because an unknown error occurred. try saving to a different location." (see attached screenshot). This happens in Firefox 95.0 on my Linux machine.

To reproduce the problem, all you need to do is open a website and click on a link that tries to download a file - then just sit back and watch as the error message appears! It seems to be related to this new setting called "browser.download.improvements_to_download_panel" being enabled by default. I tested it with Mozregression, which pointed me towards a specific commit (d129398) in Phabricator, and sure enough, if I disable that setting, the problem goes away and downloads work as normal again.

created attachment 9339698
testcase.html

after allocate memory to exhaust the process virtual memory and execute invalid js function inside try {} catch() {} and input pattern. on firefox 32-bit it able to crash on js_getproperty on address 0x000083d8, more interestingly on firefox 64-bit it able to crash on dynamic (changing) address including 0x00050512fab2b080, 0x000514975972b080, 0x000526aa3e72b080, and more..

currently the testcase.html is fine-tuned to make it very reliably to reproduce on firefox 114.0.1 (32-bit) on windows 11, i tested this very reliably crash on js_getproperty on both my machine intel i9-13900k and amd ryzen 7 5700g, it still able to crash on firefox nightly 116.0a1 (2023-06-16) (32-bit), but reduced success rate and have to adjust fillmemory code to make it very reliably on nightly. for now i decided to submit this report and adjust that later.

## tested on:
- firefox 114.0.1 (32-bit)
- firefox 114.0.1 (64-bit)
- firefox nightly 116.0a1 (2023-06-16) (32-bit)
- firefox nightly 116.0a1 (2023-06-16) (64-bit)

## steps to reproduce:
1. open firefox 114.0.1 (32-bit)
2. visit attached testcase.html
3. wait ~20 seconds
4. firefox tab crashed
5. analyze the minidump using windbg
6. firefox crash on js_getproperty -> js_forwardgetpropertyto

Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a conversational tone:

"I've got a weird issue to report! So, I created an attachment called `testcase.html` and what happens is that if you allocate a ton of memory (which exhausts the process virtual memory) and then try to execute some invalid JavaScript code inside a try-catch block with a specific input pattern, Firefox 32-bit will crash on me. What's even stranger is that when I tried it on Firefox 64-bit, it crashed on different addresses every time - like `0x00050512fab2b080`, `0x000514975972b080`, and so on.

I've fine-tuned the `testcase.html` file to make it really reliable on Firefox 114.0.1 (32-bit) on Windows 11, and I can reproduce the crash consistently on both my Intel i9-13900k and AMD Ryzen 7 5700g machines. It also works on Firefox Nightly 116.0a1 (2023-06-16) (32-bit), but the success rate is a bit lower and I need to adjust some code to make it work reliably there.

Here are the details of what I tested:

* Firefox 114.0.1 (32-bit)
* Firefox 114.0.1 (64-bit)
* Firefox Nightly 116.0a1 (2023-06-16) (32-bit)
* Firefox Nightly 116.0a1 (2023-06-16) (64-bit)

1. Open Firefox 114.0.1 (32-bit)
2. Visit the attached `testcase.html`
3. Wait about 20 seconds
4. The Firefox tab will crash
5. Use Windbg to analyze the minidump and see that it crashes on `js_getproperty` -> `js_forwardgetpropertyto`.

created attachment 9319750
testcase.html

i found that by adding code to request permission dialog, tab loading + slowdown code, and window.history.back() when in the middle of requestfullscreen it able to turning the browser into full screen mode without fullscreen notification toast.

on mozregression i able to reproduce this after commit [bug 1800482 - track fullscreen-request-origin in top-level chrome browsing context](https://phabricator.services.mozilla.com/d162021). after the commit on this testcase it throw error on browser console `typeerror: can't access property "ownerglobal", topbc.embedderelement is null`.

## tested on:
- firefox nightly 112.0a1 (2023-02-24) (64-bit) on windows 11
 
## steps to reproduce:
1. open firefox nightly on windows 11
2. download attached testcase.html
3. serve the file with `python -m http.server`
4. visit 127.0.0.1:8000
5. on directory listing click "testcase.html" link
6. click anywhere on the page
7. browser goes to fullscreen without fullscreen notification toast
user_behviou: Best
NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a casual, conversational tone:

"I've been playing around with this weird behavior I found where adding some specific code can actually get my browser into full screen mode without showing that annoying 'You're going full screen' toast! It happened when I combined three things: permission dialog code, tab loading and slowdown stuff, and the `window.history.back()` trick. I was able to reproduce it after a certain commit (bug 1800482) which changed how Firefox handles full screen requests in top-level browsing contexts. Now, when I try this on my nightly build of Firefox on Windows 11, it throws an error in the console saying that it can't access some property called 'ownerglobal' because `topbc.embedderelement` is null. To reproduce this, you'll need to follow these steps: first, grab a copy of the attached `testcase.html` file and serve it using Python's built-in HTTP server (just run `python -m http.server`). Then, visit `127.0.0.1:8000`, navigate to the directory listing, click on the `testcase.html` link, tap anywhere on the page, and voila! Your browser should go into full screen mode without warning."

text:
created attachment 9232191
broken_darkening_of_window_control_buttons.png

#### steps to reproduce:
1. launch firefox (at least version 90.0 stable)
2. do basically anything that makes the new proton window modal appear, e.g. click: application menu > help > troubleshoot mode.
3. look at the top right corner of the firefox window and see what is described in the "actual results" section.

#### actual results:
the window minimize, maximize, and close buttons are no longer susceptible to the new proton window-modal darkening (see attached screenshot).

#### expected results:
the window control buttons should become darker when the new proton window modal is displayed, as in version 89.0 stable.

#### additional context:
if i understood everything correctly, the story here is as follows:
1. when proton was introduced in firefox 89.0, the window minimize, maximize, and close buttons were displayed correctly and were susceptible to the new proton window-modal darkening.
2. changes made to fix bug 1696905 broke the window control buttons on windows 8.1 and made them appear as a black rectangle.
3. to fix this regression (i.e. bug 1709535), some changes was made. they actually fixed it — the black rectangle disappeared — but the initial correct behavior from point 1. above (i.e. to darken also the window controls when the new proton window modal is displayed) has not been restored, unfortunately.

unfortunately, due to the black rectangle in windows 8.1, i were not able to check whether the darkening of the window minimize, maximize, and close buttons has been broken when trying to fix bug 1709535, or maybe earlier — when trying to fix bug 1696905.
user_behviou: Best

So, I've got a weird issue with Firefox. When I launch the browser and then click on the help menu to get into troubleshoot mode (just one example - it happens whenever that new Proton window modal pops up), something strange happens. Instead of the usual darkening effect on the minimize, maximize, and close buttons in the top right corner of the window, they just freeze as black rectangles like this [attachment 9232191: broken_darkening_of_window_control_buttons.png]. What I'm expecting is that those buttons should get darker when the Proton modal shows up, just like it did before (in Firefox 89.0, specifically). It seems like some changes made to fix another bug broke this behavior on my Windows 8.1 machine, and now we're stuck with these weird black rectangles instead of the nice darkening effect.

Here's the rewritten bug report:

I'm reporting an issue with Autofill on certain credit card fields when trying to pay on the Jack Wolfskin website (www.jack-wolfskin.de). I've noticed this problem in Firefox versions 111.0a1, 110.0b5, and 109.0, as well as Windows 10, macOS 11, and Ubuntu 20 platforms. To reproduce the issue, you'll need to have at least one credit card saved, with browser.search.region set. Here's what I did:

1. Reach the payment form on www.jack-wolfskin.de.
2. Select any saved credit card entry from the drop-down in the credit card number field.
3. Click on the expiry date fields and then click again on the credit card name field and select another saved credit card entry.

What I expected to happen was that all eligible fields would autofill and highlight, with the cc drop-down displayed for each field. But instead:

1. The cc name field didn't autofill, and the expiry date fields weren't highlighted. When I selected a cc entry from the card name field, only that field was autofilled.
2. The cc drop-down wasn't displayed after those fields autofilled.

Notably, this issue doesn't seem to be a recent regression, but it's still not working as expected. Interestingly, when I tested in Chrome separately, the cc name field did work as expected - it's just the other fields that are causing trouble.

in end-to-end encryption, in the openpgp section, select "none" even if a pgp key is available. (in my case, this was a key i created decades ago and was sitting on my computer all this time.)

in the s/mime section, select a valid s/mime certificate. 



actual results:

when sending an email, openpgp is chosen as the signature method by default. for every message, it's necessary to choose s/mime. otherwise you get the error dialog "openpgp alert - cannot digitally sign this message, because you haven’t yet configured end-to-end encryption for <email address>".


expected results:

s/mime should have been automatically selected, since no pgp key was chosen. 

for more details (how i solved the problem on the user-interface level), please see

https://support.mozilla.org/en-us/questions/1391269

note that this is a change of behavior from previous versions of thunderbird. prior versions would automatically select s/mime if no openpgp signature was selected in the account settings.

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

"I'm using Thunderbird version 102.3.1 on my Mac, and I've noticed an issue with end-to-end encryption. When I go to set up OpenPGP, I expect it to default to "none" since there isn't a PGP key available - which is exactly what happens when I select that option. The problem is that when I then try to send an email, Thunderbird automatically chooses OpenPGP as the signature method instead of S/MIME. This is even though I've selected a valid S/MIME certificate in my account settings! If I don't explicitly choose S/MIME for each message, I get an error message saying "OpenPGP alert - cannot digitally sign this message, because you haven’t yet configured end-to-end encryption for <email address>". 

What's weird is that this didn't used to be the case. In previous versions of Thunderbird, if no OpenPGP signature was selected in my account settings, it would automatically default to S/MIME instead. So, I'm thinking maybe this is a change in behavior or something? Anyway, the expected result would be for S/MIME to be chosen by default since there's no PGP key available, and users shouldn't have to manually switch between the two signature methods all the time."

steps to reproduce:

i created a small test case to show that scroll events stop working if a synchronous xhr request is startet while scrolling an iframe.

in the test case there is a scroll listener that logs the current y scroll position, each time you scroll. also there is a simple xhr request, started after 5s timeout.
if you keep on scrolling while the request is started you can see that the listener stops to log the y position. there is also no error on the console. 
if you do not scroll while the the request is started (only before and after), everything works as expected.
see video and test case package. this behavior/bug was introduced with firefox 66.

steps:
- open https://codesandbox.io/s/hardcore-lamport-1l11b or attached zip file (local webserver)
- open native firefox dev tools / console
- keep scrolling
-- you will see logs of your scroll position until the request after 5s is started

scroll events stop working after synchronous xhr request while scrolling an iframe.


expected results:

scroll events should work no matter if there is a synchronous xhr request while scrolling an iframe.

"Hey, I've got a weird issue to report. So, I created this test case to show that scroll events stop working when you're making a synchronous XHR request while scrolling within an iframe. Here's what happens: I set up a simple listener that logs the current Y position every time you scroll. Then, after a 5-second delay, I trigger a synchronous XHR request. If you keep scrolling during this request (or even just start scrolling shortly before), the listener stops logging positions and nothing shows up in the console log either. It's like the scroll events just freeze! But if you don't touch the scrollbar while the request is running (only before or after), everything works as expected. I've attached a test case package with the video, so you can see it for yourself. This bug seems to have started with Firefox 66."

text:
created attachment 9338259
proposed patch

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (x11; linux x86_64; rv:109.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/114.0

steps to reproduce:

running libcacard tests under valgrind:

https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/spice/libcacard/-/issues/15

this points to the use of `flagseries` and `flagstate` members, which are not initialized during the structure initialization and first tested in `secmod_handlewaitforslotevent` (and value is assigned to them only after the first test). i believe the correct fix is to make sure they are initialized when the structure is allocated otherwise it might cause unexpected behavior.

this is available in the master.


actual results:

valgrind reports memory issues pointing to nss:
```
==44832== thread 3:
==44832== conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)
==44832==    at 0x4ac98a7: secmod_handlewaitforslotevent (pk11util.c:1181)
==44832==    by 0x4ac9bcd: secmod_waitforanytokenevent (pk11util.c:1252)
==44832==    by 0x4860dfe: vcard_emul_event_thread (vcard_emul_nss.c:830)
==44832==    by 0x4c04758: _pt_root (ptthread.c:201)
==44832==    by 0x4cb5906: start_thread (pthread_create.c:444)
==44832==    by 0x4d3b773: clone (clone.s:100)
==44832== 
```


expected results:

nss should not use uninitialized memory

NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

I'm reporting an issue with libcacard tests running under Valgrind. It looks like there's a problem with two structure members - `flagseries` and `flagstate` - that aren't being initialized when they're first used in the `secmod_handlewaitforslotevent` function (and only get assigned values after the fact). I think the fix is to make sure these guys are properly set up when the structure is created, or we might see some weird behavior. This issue is actually already fixed on the master branch, but it's still worth reporting since it could cause problems for people running Valgrind tests. When I ran the test under Valgrind, it spat out a bunch of memory-related warnings pointing to NSS: "conditional jump or move depends on uninitialized value(s)" - basically, it's saying that NSS is trying to use some memory that hasn't been initialized yet, which is definitely not what we want!

"I've noticed this weird behavior since Firefox 98 - whenever I try to download a PDF from a server that doesn't support online viewing, I get three options: 'Open with Firefox', 'Open with [list of apps]', and 'Download'. Now, when I click on 'Open with Firefox' like I used to do, it's not saving the PDF in my default download location (which is usually the 'Downloads' folder) - instead, it saves it temporarily and opens it directly in Firefox. But here's the thing: starting from version 98, every PDF I try to download using this method gets saved to the 'Downloads' folder permanently! This is a big problem because my downloads folder gets cluttered quickly, making it hard for me to distinguish between legitimate downloads and temporary ones that I might not need anymore."

created attachment 9217045
space between rows.png

**[affected versions]:**
- firefox nightly 89.0a1 (build id: 20210417095008)
- firefox nightly 90.0a1 (build id: 20210419221626)

**[affected platforms]:**
- linux mint 20
- windows 10
- macos 11.1

**[prerequisites]:**
- have firefox open.
- from the “about:config” page, have `signon.management.page.fileimport.enabled` set to `true`.
- have a correct csv file containing valid login data.

**[steps to reproduce]:**
1. navigate to “about:logins”.
2. click the meatball menu button (“...”).
3. choose the “import from a file...” option.
4. choose the csv from prerequisites and import it.
5. observe the text of the “import complete” modal.

**[expected result]:**
- the space between the rows of text is smaller.

**[actual result]:**
- the space between the rows of text is larger than in the [documentation](https://mozilla.invisionapp.com/share/r3xx2af2xn5#/screens/423736091).

**[notes]:**
- this issue is also applicable for the “import error” modal.
- the issue seems to have been introduced as a fix in bug 1701690.
- attached is a screenshot of the issue compared to the documentation.
user_behviou: Good
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten paragraph:

Hey, so I noticed something weird happening when I tried to import login data from a CSV file into Firefox. It started with me having the browser open and enabling some settings in about:config - specifically, signon.management.page.fileimport.enabled needed to be set to true. Then, I had a valid CSV file ready with my login credentials. From there, I went to about:logins, clicked the three dots (meatball menu), chose "Import from a file...", picked the CSV, and imported it. After that, I just observed what happened in the "import complete" modal - and honestly, it wasn't what I expected! According to the documentation, there should be some space between the rows of text, but instead, it's way larger than it should be. It gets even weirder because this issue also affects the "import error" modal. And get this - it seems like this problem was introduced as a fix for bug 1701690 (not that I'm complaining about the original fix or anything). Anyways, I attached a screenshot showing the difference between what's supposed to happen and what actually happens - thought you might find it helpful!

text:
user agent: mozilla/5.0 (x11; linux x86_64; rv:89.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/89.0

steps to reproduce:

i'm using a smart card certificate for authentication to a website.
it seems like i've used the "remember this decision" feature before.

everything was working fine, but i've recently renewed my expiring smart card certificate.

whenever i visit this website now, i immediately get a ssl_error_expired_cert_alert error. i don't get a prompt asking me which certificate to use.


actual results:

looks like firefox was using a now-expired certificate -- some remembered decision from before.

it didn't provide a prompt telling me that there are other options (i do have a renewed certificate on this smart card now).

it didn't point me to settings > privacy & security > view certificates > authentication decisions, where i could manage such remembered decisions.

in any case, going to settings > privacy & security > view certificates > authentication decisions, i didn't see any remembered decisions that i could clear.

i have ended up manually deleting entries from the `clientauthrememberlist.txt` file in my profile directory, which solved the problem.


expected results:

i expect that firefox would notice that this certificate is expired and bring the "prompt" again, despite me having said "remember this decision" some few years ago.

i also expect that whenever an error like ssl_error_expired_cert_alert (or similar) happens, firefox would bring up a prompt asking for another certificate. authentication has obviously failed, so it should provide other options instead of insisting on this.

it may have also told me about such remembered decisions and point me to settings > privacy & security > view certificates > authentication decisions, so i can edit these decisions.

in any case, i would have expected that the "authentication decisions" feature worked. it seems like it currently doesn't list anything.

----

seems like this is 2 issues in one:

- (bug) "authentication decisions" showed nothing, while there were obviously some remembered decisions, which i could clear manually from `clientauthrememberlist.txt`

- (enhancement) improving the current behavior -- selecting an expired certificate and not giving me other options or guides, but merely an `ssl_error_expired_cert_alert` error is not friendly

NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

"I'm using Firefox 89.0 on Linux, and I've run into a weird issue with smart card certificates. So, I use a smart card for authentication to a specific website, and I've got 'remember this decision' enabled because it's a hassle to input my credentials every time. Everything was working smoothly until I renewed my expiring certificate - now whenever I visit that website, Firefox gives me an SSL error saying the certificate is expired. The weird part is that I don't get prompted to choose which certificate to use; instead, it just shows me the error message.

What's even weirder is that I think this issue is related to some remembered decision from before. Apparently, Firefox was still using my old, expired certificate and didn't offer any alternatives or hints about what was going on. I had to manually go into settings > privacy & security > view certificates > authentication decisions to clear out the remembered decisions - and even then, there were none listed!

What I expect is that when an error like this happens, Firefox should realize the certificate's expired and give me the option to choose a new one. It should also provide some guidance on how to fix the issue or manage my remembered decisions. Instead, it just showed me the error message and didn't offer any help.

It seems like there are two issues here: (1) 'authentication decisions' is broken and doesn't show anything, even though I can clear out remembered decisions manually; and (2) when an expired certificate's used, Firefox should provide a more friendly experience, like offering alternative certificates or guiding me to fix the issue.

NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a conversational tone:

"I'm experiencing an issue with Firefox 96.0.1 on Linux Mint (also tested on the official Mozilla release). When I set 'pdfjs.enablepermissions' to false in the `/etc/firefox/policies/policies.json` file, it doesn't actually disable the option. Instead, when I check about:policies#active, it shows that the option is correctly recognized and set to false - but if I go to about:config, it's still locked and set to true. This means I can't copy text from PDFs (tested with this example file: https://h24-files.s3.amazonaws.com/65073/161759-fduyc.pdf). To reproduce the issue:

1. Set `/etc/firefox/policies/policies.json` to `{ "policies": { "pdfjs": { "enablepermissions": false } } }`
2. Start a new Firefox profile
3. Check about:policies#active to see that the option is correctly set to false

The weird thing is, if I explicitly enable or disable 'pdfjs.enablepermissions' in about:config, it works as expected - so it's only when setting this option through the policies file that it gets stuck. On a related note, if I set `enabled` and `enablepermissions` both to false in the policies file, it does work correctly. And if I set 'pdfjs.enablepermissions' directly in the preferences, it also works as expected. But for some reason, setting it through the policies file keeps 'pdfjs(enablepermissions locked and true.' That's what I'm trying to report - the actual result is that 'pdfjs.enablepermissions' is stuck at true when set through the policies file."

ss of the issue.png

**[affected versions]:**
- firefox beta 100.0 - build id: 20220425210429

**[affected platforms]:**
- windows 10 x64
- macos 11.6.2

**[prerequisites]:**
- have a firefox en-* locale build installed.
- have a firefox profile older than 28 days
- firefox is not pinned to the taskbar/dock.
- have the "[user.js](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lkxdsxtwit23cmv9wect72y_um3v0cxi/view?usp=sharing)" file saved to your pc.

**[steps to reproduce]:**
1. open the browser using the profile from the prerequisites.
2. navigate to the profile folder and paste the "user.js" file from the prerequisites.
3. restart the browser and focus the "browser console".
4. observe the displayed errors.

**[expected result]:**
- no error is displayed and you are successfully enrolled in the experiment.

**[actual result]:**
- a validation error is displayed and you are not enrolled in the experiment.

**[notes]:**
- this issue is not reproducible if a force enrollment is performed instead of a natural one.
- attached a screenshot of the error.
user_behviou: "good"
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

So, I've been testing out Firefox beta 100.0 on both Windows 10 and Mac OS 11.6.2, and I found this weird issue that I wanted to report. To reproduce it, you need to have a Firefox build with an en-* locale (whatever that means), a profile older than 28 days, and the browser not pinned to the taskbar or dock. Oh, and you also need to save this specific "user.js" file on your computer - don't ask me why, but it's required for some reason! 

To reproduce the issue, follow these steps: open Firefox with that old profile, navigate to its folder and paste in the "user.js" file, restart the browser, focus the "browser console", and then just observe what happens. What I saw was a bunch of errors popping up - not exactly what I expected! 

Normally, when you do this, you should be enrolled in some experiment without any issues. But instead, I got a validation error saying it didn't work out. Weird, right? And the craziest thing is that if I force the enrollment instead of doing it normally, the issue disappears - it's like it knows what's up!

NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a conversational tone:

"I encountered an issue with Firefox when I enabled Windows' high-contrast mode with the 'high contrast black' theme and set my browser appearance to match the system theme. When I visited this specific CodePen page (https://codepen.io/simondl/pen/ondgpde) in Firefox, I noticed that the layout was off. To be specific, divs 1 and 3 took up the full width of the screen, while div 2 was narrow. What's weird is that when I tried this same test on Chromium-based browsers, everything looked as expected - all three divs were nice and narrow. It seems like Firefox is having some trouble respecting the forced colors standard, which is described in more detail here (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-us/docs/web/css/@media/forced-colors#active) and here (https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2020/09/17/styling-for-windows-high-contrast-with-new-standards-for-forced-colors/#file-forced-colors-2-css-l1). According to those standards, I should see all three divs being narrow, but instead Firefox is acting weirdly. Maybe someone can help me troubleshoot this issue!"

To reproduce it, you need to create a new Firefox profile, enable the 'nimbus.debug' preference in about:config, and then follow these steps: First, navigate to this experiment page [www.amazon.com](http://www.amazon.com), click on any product, and then agree to try out the "review checker" feature. Hey, I wanted to file a bug report because I'm experiencing some weird issues with Firefox Beta (version 122.0b9). Specifically, when I record audio on any website that lets me do so (like online-voice-recorder.com), the playback is super distorted - like, it's basically unrecognizable. Here's the rewritten bug report:

I'm reporting a weird issue I found in Firefox - when you try to delete a profile, the modal window that pops up doesn't behave as expected. Instead of showing up normally, it shifts down a few millimeters. This is happening on my Macs (running macOS 12, 11, and 10.15) and also on someone else's machine with Firefox 110.0b3 installed. It seems to be affecting only the macOS platforms - Windows 10 and Ubuntu 22 are fine. To reproduce this issue, just follow these steps: launch Firefox, go to about:profiles, create a new profile, then click the "delete" button. You should see that modal window I mentioned, but it'll be shifted down instead of showing up normally. This started happening after the build from January 11th - before that, everything was fine. If you want more details, check out the attached screen recording or notes for this bug report.

bookmark suggestion shown in 117.0a1, but in wrong section

### steps to reproduce

1. start with a clean profile
2. go to "settings" -> "search" -> disable "show search suggestions" (disabling it only for private browsing mode is sufficient to reproduce it in pb mode)
3. open website, e.g. "example.org", in private browsing mode (so that there will be no history entry)
4. add website as bookmark
5. close tab
6. in a new (private browsing) tab start typing "example" into url bar

### expected behavior
bookmarked website should show up as suggestion

### actual behavior
in most cases, no suggestions are shown. sometimes the bookmarked website is shown but is listed as google search result (see attached screenshot).
it does work correctly when either
- there is any history entry that matches the search string
- search browsing history is disabled
- bookmarks search engine is selected
- search suggestions are enabled

### device information

* firefox version: 115.2.1, 116.0b8, 117.0a1
* android device model: pixel 4a
* android os version: 13

### any additional information?
i think this is a regression in 115. this is an annoying issue when you are always using only private browsing mode.

steps to reproduce:

## title
  - firefox webgl glvminterpretfptransformfour oob access vulnerability

## summary
  - a oob access vulnerability exists in the webgl glvminterpretfptransformfour
  - the browser process crashes when triggering this bug.

## test environment
  - product : mozilla firefox 105.0.3
  - os : macos monterey 12.6 (m1 pro arm)
  
## root cause analysis
  ```
  * thread #25, name = 'canvasrenderer', queue = 'openglmt', stop reason = exc_bad_access (code=2, address=0x1715efff8)
    frame #0: 0x00000001ade070cc libsystem_pthread.dylib`___chkstk_darwin + 60
libsystem_pthread.dylib`:
->  0x1ade070cc <+60>: ldur   x11, [x11, #-0x8]
    0x1ade070d0 <+64>: mov    x10, sp
    0x1ade070d4 <+68>: cmp    x9, #0x1, lsl #12         ; =0x1000
    0x1ade070d8 <+72>: b.lo   0x1ade070f0               ; <+96>
target 0: (firefox) stopped.
(lldb) bt
* thread #25, name = 'canvasrenderer', queue = 'openglmt', stop reason = exc_bad_access (code=2, address=0x1715efff8)
  * frame #0: 0x00000001ade070cc libsystem_pthread.dylib`___chkstk_darwin + 60
    frame #1: 0x000000020f692db4 libglprogrammability.dylib`glvminterpretfptransformfour + 424
    frame #2: 0x000000020f913b88 glrendererfloat`gldllvmfptransformfallback + 444
    frame #3: 0x000000020f915cb8 glrendererfloat`gldllvmvecpointrender + 6940
    frame #4: 0x000000020f90e5c0 glrendererfloat`gldrenderpoints + 76
    frame #5: 0x000000020f8e0524 glengine`glellvmvecprimpointrender + 1684
    frame #6: 0x000000020f83b88c glengine`gldrawarraysinstanced_std_gl3exec + 1296
    frame #7: 0x000000020f83acd8 glengine`gldrawarrays_unpackthread + 48
    frame #8: 0x000000020f87689c glengine`glecmdprocessor + 116
    frame #9: 0x00000001adc481b4 libdispatch.dylib`_dispatch_client_callout + 20
    frame #10: 0x00000001adc57414 libdispatch.dylib`_dispatch_lane_barrier_sync_invoke_and_complete + 56
    frame #11: 0x000000020f7e2ac8 glengine`glflush_execthread + 32
    frame #12: 0x000000011106ac50 xul`___lldb_unnamed_symbol52768 + 40
    frame #13: 0x00000001114e90c8 xul`___lldb_unnamed_symbol63264 + 2252
    frame #14: 0x00000001146fd0a4 xul`___lldb_unnamed_symbol207810 + 980
    frame #15: 0x0000000113c48764 xul`___lldb_unnamed_symbol166963 + 312
    frame #16: 0x0000000110e907e8 xul`___lldb_unnamed_symbol49031 + 756
    frame #17: 0x0000000110e91a24 xul`___lldb_unnamed_symbol49039 + 168
    frame #18: 0x0000000110c15b4c xul`___lldb_unnamed_symbol41826 + 4308
    frame #19: 0x0000000110e945d0 xul`___lldb_unnamed_symbol49067 + 476
    frame #20: 0x0000000110e5ceb8 xul`___lldb_unnamed_symbol48460 + 80
    frame #21: 0x0000000110c0ea24 xul`___lldb_unnamed_symbol41796 + 288
    frame #22: 0x0000000100f46fa8 libnss3.dylib`___lldb_unnamed_symbol2250 + 260
    frame #23: 0x00000001ade0c26c libsystem_pthread.dylib`_pthread_start + 148
(lldb) mem read 0x1715efff8

  ```

  - if you debug at the point where the crash occurred, you can see that the crash occurred in openglmt.

  - this bug is an out-of-bounds access vulnerability that occurs in webgl's handling of the drawelements command.

## proof-of-concept
  - please check the attached file!

## reproduce
  - open a poc.html in firefox
  - wait a few seconds.

  - dohyun lee (@l33d0hyun) of ssd labs

user_behviou: Good
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

I recently discovered an out-of-bounds access vulnerability in Firefox's WebGL implementation. Specifically, it affects the `glvminterpretfptransformfour` function when handling the `drawelements` command.

To reproduce this issue, you can follow these steps: open a test file called `poc.html` using Firefox (version 105.0.3) on my Mac running macOS Monterey 12.6 with an M1 Pro chip. Just wait for about a few seconds and the browser process will crash.

From my debugging analysis, it looks like the problem occurs in the OpenGLMT thread when trying to access memory at address `0x1715efff8`. When I looked deeper into the code, I found that the crash happens in the `glvminterpretfptransformfour` function.

The proof-of-concept file is attached for your reference. To trigger the bug, simply open the test HTML file and wait a few seconds - you should see the browser process crash.

I'm Do-hyun Lee from SSD Labs, and I'd love to share more details or help you investigate further if needed!

created attachment 9349809
side-by-side of chrome and firefox on the same machine, with the wacom driver installed, showing the difference in evaluated css mq4 imfs

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 10.0; win64; x64) applewebkit/537.36 (khtml, like gecko) chrome/115.0.0.0 safari/537.36

steps to reproduce:

on windows, with the wacom tablet driver installed (but no actual wacom tablet attached/used, just navigating with mouse):

* open https://patrickhlauke.github.io/touch/pointer-hover-any-pointer-any-hover/
* review how the various interaction media features (pointer, hover, any-pointer, any-hover) are evaluated


actual results:

when the wacom driver is installed on windows, even if there isn't an actual wacom tablet attached (just navigating with the mouse as normal), firefox seems to get confused and evaluates the following (as if there was only a touch interface present):

pointer:coarse true
pointer:fine false
hover:none true
hover:hover false
any-pointer:coarse true
any-pointer:fine false
any-hover:none true
any-hover:hover false




expected results:

the mere presence of the wacom tablet driver (without a tablet attached) should have no impact on the interaction media features. so i'd expect simply

pointer:coarse false
pointer:fine true
hover:none false
hover:hover true
any-pointer:coarse false
any-pointer:fine true
any-hover:none false
any-hover:hover true

once a tablet is attached, i'd generally expect firefox to still choose/decide that the mouse is the primary input device - so pointer and hover should evaluate the same as above, but have any-pointer:coarse true:

pointer:coarse false
pointer:fine true
hover:none false
hover:hover true
*any-pointer:coarse true*
any-pointer:fine true
any-hover:none false
any-hover:hover true

at a stretch, if firefox is keen to see the tablet (once present) as the primary input, then at the very least i'd expect

*pointer:coarse true*
*pointer:fine false*
*hover:none true*
*hover:hover false*
*any-pointer:coarse true*
*any-pointer:fine true*
any-hover:none false
*any-hover:hover true*


note that uninstalling the wacom tablet driver and restarting the machine, firefox then shows the correct/expected results (for a mouse-driven machine).

compare this to chrome on windows, which behaves correctly with the driver installed (have not tested what happens with actual wacom tablet attached though, but from memory it behaves like the above "once a tablet is attached" scenario.

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

I noticed something weird when I had the Wacom driver installed on my Windows machine, even though I wasn't actually using a Wacom tablet (just navigating with my mouse). When I opened this website - https://patrickhlauke.github.io/touch/pointer-hover-any-pointer-any-hover/ - which shows how different interaction media features are evaluated, Firefox got confused. It started acting like there was only a touch interface present, evaluating the media features as if that were true.

Here's what it did:

* pointer: coarse, fine (both false)
* hover: none, hover (both true)
* any-pointer: coarse, fine (both false)
* any-hover: none, hover (both true)

I expected Firefox to behave normally, without the Wacom driver messing things up. But once I uninstalled the driver and restarted my machine, everything went back to normal.

The weird thing is that Chrome doesn't have this issue - even with the Wacom driver installed, it behaves correctly (at least, as far as I remember). It's like Firefox thinks there's a touch interface present just because the Wacom driver is installed, even when no tablet is attached.

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 10.0; win64; x64) applewebkit/537.36 (khtml, like gecko) chrome/105.0.0.0 safari/537.36

steps to reproduce:

> 1.    how your ca first became aware of the problem (e.g. via a problem report submitted to your problem reporting mechanism, a discussion in mozilla.dev.security.policy, a bugzilla bug, or internal self-audit), and the time and date.

entrust became aware of the problem on 15 september 2022 at 12:01 utc, when the post linting check indicated that there was a tls certificate issued of which the state or province value was not included on a pre-approved list.
 
> 2.    a timeline of the actions your ca took in response. a timeline is a date-and-time-stamped sequence of all relevant events. this may include events before the incident was reported, such as when a particular requirement became applicable, or a document changed, or a bug was introduced, or an audit was done.
 
-	**2022-09-15 11:31 utc** - certificate issued 
-	**2022-09-15 12:01 utc** - detection by post issuance linter
-	**2022-09-15 14:17 utc** - issue confirmed by validation specialist 
-	**2022-09-15 15:33 utc** - certificate reissued
-	**2022-09-20 14:03 utc ** - certificate revoked

> 3.   whether your ca has stopped, or has not yet stopped, issuing certificates with the problem. a statement that you have will be considered a pledge to the community; a statement that you have not requires an explanation.

entrust has not stopped issuance. similar issues will be detected post issuance and revoked within 24 hours until the development work to only accept pre-approved state or province values has been completed and deployed to production. 
 
> 4.    a summary of the problematic certificates. for each problem: number of certs, and the date the first and last certs with that problem were issued.

the impacted certificate is listed in item 5.

> 5.    the complete certificate data for the problematic certificates.

https://crt.sh/?id=7546397880 – revoked at 2022-09-20 14:03 utc

> 6.    explanation about how and why the mistakes were made or bugs introduced, and how they avoided detection until now.

the problem was detected directly after issuance by our post-issuance linting.

issuance was not prevented because: 
-	the verification team approved the subject dn without resolving the error as indicated by the administration system. the administration system compares the st field to the country subdivisions in a pre-approved list based on iso 3166. the override is available in the event there is a difference of the verified st field and the pre-approved list.
-	no check was implemented in pre-issuance linting which is based on zlint. 

> 7.    list of steps your ca is taking to resolve the situation and ensure such issuance will not be repeated in the future, accompanied with a timeline of when your ca expects to accomplish these things.

the certificate request system is being migrated to complete the st field based on a drop down  populated by the pre-approved list. the system which had the issue has not yet been migrated. the migration will be complete by 15 december 2022.

entrust has escalated guidance with our verification team on reviewing this field and correcting this field , if required. entrust continue to perform post-issuance linting to check for any errors.
user_behviou: good
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

We first noticed an issue on September 15th, 2022 at 12:01 UTC when our post-linting check picked up that a TLS certificate was issued with a state or province value that wasn't on our pre-approved list. Here's what happened next:

* September 15th, 11:31 UTC: The certificate was issued
* September 15th, 12:01 UTC: Our post-issuance linter detected the problem
* September 15th, 14:17 UTC: A validation specialist confirmed the issue
* September 15th, 15:33 UTC: We reissued the certificate
* September 20th, 14:03 UTC: We revoked the certificate

We haven't stopped issuing certificates with this problem, but we'll continue to detect and revoke similar issues until we complete some development work to only accept pre-approved state or province values.

The impacted certificate is listed below:

https://crt.sh/?id=7546397880 (revoked on September 20th, 2022 at 14:03 UTC)

As for how this mistake happened, it was because our verification team approved the subject DN without resolving an error that showed up in our administration system. This system compares the ST field to a pre-approved list based on ISO 3166, and we didn't have a check in place during pre-issuance linting.

To fix this situation and prevent it from happening again, we're taking the following steps:

* We're migrating our certificate request system to require the ST field to be populated from a dropdown menu with our pre-approved list
* We've escalated guidance to our verification team on reviewing and correcting this field if needed
* We'll continue to perform post-issuance linting to catch any errors

We expect to complete the migration by December 15th, 2022.

text:
created attachment 9235381
bildschirmfoto 2021-08-09 um 14.18.06.png

[summarizing up to comment 18 -dveditz] this user had a legacy cookie permission in the site permissions database that broke the "manage exceptions" dialog for cookies -- it simply wouldn't appear. this was because one of their cookies permissions, apparently added in 2017, had a capability of `9` which was formerly used for access_allow_first_party_only. as a result the localization routine threw an exception (see comment 5) because it only expected values `0`, `1`, and `2`. this exception was not caught which nerfed the dialog.

folks with old profiles, especially those who actively manage their cookies, might have any of several different obsolete values saved in the site permissions database. that should not break the management dialogs!  it looks like the network code ignores cookie permission entries with unexpected values so the simple solution would be to likewise simply ignore those entries and don't display them in the dialog. or you could proactively delete invalid entries.

===== original bug entry: ======
user agent: mozilla/5.0 (macintosh; intel mac os x 10.14; rv:90.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/90.0

steps to reproduce:

i went to about:preferences#privacy and clicked the button "manage exceptions" in the cookies section


actual results:

nothing


expected results:

a dialog window should have opened that lists all cookie exceptions. i use this feature relatively frequently and it never had any issues. but now when i click the button, nothing happend. all the other buttons on the page work normally.

i also notice that after clicking the "manage exceptions" button, i can't scroll the page any more. i have to navigate to some other page and then back to make it work again.

Here's my evaluation:

**Content:** Good

**Grammar:** Best

As for the required sections:

1. **Steps to Reproduce (S2R):** Good
The user provides a clear, concise description of how to reproduce the issue.
2. **Expected Result (ER):** Good
The expected result is clearly stated, allowing developers to understand what the user intended to happen.
3. **Actual Result (AR):** Good
The actual result is also well-described, helping developers to understand the problem.

4. **Additional Information:** Good
The report includes relevant details such as software version and build number, which can be helpful for debugging.

Overall, I would rate this bug report as "Best" because it provides a clear summary of the issue, its cause, and potential solutions, along with well-written steps to reproduce and expected results.
NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

"I was trying to manage my cookie exceptions on Firefox, but when I clicked the 'Manage Exceptions' button under the Cookies section in Preferences > Privacy, nothing happened! Usually, this opens up a dialog window showing all the cookie exceptions I've set up. But now, it just doesn't show up at all.

What's even weirder is that after clicking the button, I couldn't scroll the page anymore - it was like the whole thing froze. I had to navigate away and then back to get scrolling working again. 

It turns out that one of my old cookie permissions from 2017 has an outdated capability value (it's a `9` instead of one of the usual `0`, `1`, or `2`). This is causing some localization routine to throw an exception, which isn't getting caught and is basically breaking the dialog. I'm guessing that other people with older profiles might have similar issues if they're actively managing their cookies.

The solution seems pretty simple: just ignore those old, outdated permission entries and don't display them in the dialog. Or, we could proactively delete any invalid entries to keep things working smoothly."

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (x11; ubuntu; linux x86_64; rv:109.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/118.0

steps to reproduce:

version 115.3.1 (supernova) of thunderbird running under x86_64 ubuntu 23.04 (gnome) as a normal (apt installed) application has a bug, where for some (?) emails i am unable to view and select an attachment for displaying it.

in the preview pane or in the separate message window (displayed when i double-click on the message) i scroll down to see the list of attachments at the bottom, but nothing is displayed except the main message's contents, as if the message has no attachment(s). so, i am unable to select and view an attachment.

this happens for new or old archived messages. however, some messages do not have this problem and it looks like the reason of displaying or not displaying the attachment section after the end of the message content cannot be determined.


actual results:

problem: for some emails, i am unable to select and view an attachment.

workaround: for those emails, selecting "view » message body as » simple html" corrects the problem and the attachment list is displayed at the bottom as it should be. but, "view » message body as » original html" hides the attachments again.


expected results:

for all emails with attachment(s), the list of all attachments should be displayed at the bottom of the message window or preview pane, regardless of the "view » message body as » ..." option selected.

text:
created attachment 9224382
testcase #1

**steps to reproduce**
1. load the attached testcase

**actual results**
the borders of the first two boxes are rendered incorrectly. they should render exactly the same as the third box.

**expected results**
all three boxes render exactly the same as the third box currently does.

**additional information**
the third box has `border-image-width: 1` (the initial value) which should be used as a factor of `border-width` which is explicitly specified as `27px`, so the used value for `border-image-width` is `27px`.

the first box has an explicit `border-image-width: 27px`.
the second box has an explicit `border-image-width: auto` which means we should use the `border-image-slice` value instead which is specified (for all three boxes) to be `27px`.
so the `border-image-width` used value should be `27px` for these two boxes too.

spec:
https://drafts.csswg.org/css-backgrounds-3/#the-border-image-width

fwiw, all three boxes look the same in chrome, but note that they have implemented `border-image-repeat: space` incorrectly. spec:
https://drafts.csswg.org/css-backgrounds-3/#valdef-background-repeat-space


btw, i printed out the numbers we calculate here:
https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/d3b116e554eb3546a95851e81f7ddc53d5b7e096/layout/painting/nscssrenderingborders.cpp#3845-3854
and they appear to be correct at this point.
user_behviou:
**Best**

The bug report meets all 4 criteria:

1. Steps to Reproduce (S2R): Detailed steps to replicate the issue.
2. Expected Result (ER): What you expected to happen.
3. Actual Result (AR): What actually happened.
4. Additional Information: Include relevant details such as software version, build number, environment, etc.

The report is well-structured, easy to follow, and provides all necessary information for debugging the issue.
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

I created an attachment (9224382) and tested it - when I loaded the attached file, I noticed that the borders of the first two boxes didn't look right compared to the third box. Specifically, their borders were rendered incorrectly, whereas the third box had its borders displayed perfectly. What I'm expecting is that all three boxes should have exactly the same border styling as the third one currently has. 

Here's what's going on: the third box uses the initial value of `border-image-width` (1) which gets multiplied by the explicitly set `border-width` of 27px, so it looks fine. The first box has its `border-image-width` set to exactly 27px, which makes sense. And the second box is using the default value of `auto`, which means we should use the specified `border-image-slice` value of 27px instead. 

So, according to the spec (https://drafts.csswg.org/css-backgrounds-3/#the-border-image-width), all three boxes should have a used value for `border-image-width` of 27px. That's why I think it's weird that only the first two boxes are not rendering their borders correctly.

By the way, when I checked in Chrome, all three boxes do look the same - but keep in mind that this browser is also incorrectly implementing `border-image-repeat: space`, according to the spec (https://drafts.csswg.org/css-backgrounds-3/#valdef-background-repeat-space). 

Lastly, I double-checked the calculations we did for this issue and everything seems correct at this point (see https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/d3b116e554eb3546a95851e81f7ddc53d5b7e096/layout/painting/nscssrenderingborders.cpp#3845-3854).

Here's the rewritten bug report:

I'm reporting a weird issue where I notice a flicker effect while typing in the address bar on Firefox Nightly (version 90.0a1). It happens on Windows 10, macOS 10.15.7, and Linux Mint 20 x64. To reproduce this, you'll need to have the latest Firefox Nightly installed, with some specific settings enabled: browser.urlbar.quicksuggest.enabled should be set to true, `browser.urlbar.quicksuggest.seenrestarts` to 89, `browser.urlbar.quicksuggest.showedonboardingdialog` also set to true, and finally, `browser.urlbar.experimental.firefoxsuggestlabels.enabled` should be enabled. Here's what you do: open Firefox with that profile, navigate to Amazon.com, perform three searches, close the tab and open a new one, then start typing "amazon prime" in the address bar, deleting one character at a time while observing the search suggestions displayed. What I expected was no flicker effect while typing the keyword, but what actually happens is that the sponsored URL flickers away as you type! I've attached a screen recording of this issue, and interestingly enough, it's reproducible even when the "show search suggestions ahead of browsing history in address bar results" option is unchecked. We actually had this issue fixed before (bug 1698496), but it seems to have resurfaced - hoping someone can help me squash this flicker!

created attachment 9233031
www2.liny.io_archive [21-07-26 02-11-21].har

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 10.0; win64; x64; rv:90.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/90.0

steps to reproduce:

loaded a specially crafted simple test webpage https://www2.liny.io/ which just displays a message and hosts an iframe to https://www1.liny.io/. the iframe has the 'content-security-policy' header set to "frame-ancestors 'self' https://www2.liny.io;" and no 'x-frame-options' header.


actual results:

the console displays the warning: "content security policy: ignoring ‘x-frame-options’ because of ‘frame-ancestors’ directive.", falsely incurring that both headers were detected and the ‘x-frame-options’ being ignored due to‘frame-ancestors’ directive presence.


expected results:

detect that 'content-security-policy' header is present but not the 'x-frame-options' and not display the warning at all. another option would be to display it as info or debug message but clearlly stating the ‘x-frame-options’ header will be ignored only if present. the current message suggest that both headers were detected which might inccur pointless investigations of hunting down the involved headers.
user_behviou: Good
NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

"I'm reporting an issue I ran into when testing a website with some custom settings. I loaded up this test page (https://www2.liny.io/) which just displays a message and has an iframe pointing to another site (https://www1.liny.io/). The iframe has a specific header set - 'content-security-policy' with the value "frame-ancestors 'self' https://www2.liny.io;". What's important is that there's no 'x-frame-options' header on this iframe. When I loaded the page, my browser (Mozilla Firefox 90) started spitting out a warning in the console saying: "Content Security Policy: ignoring ‘x-frame-options’ because of ‘frame-ancestors’ directive." The thing is, this warning is misleading - it makes it seem like both 'content-security-policy' and 'x-frame-options' headers were detected, when really only the former was present. Ideally, I'd want the browser to just detect the 'content-security-policy' header and not display any warnings at all, or if it does display a message, it should clearly state that the 'x-frame-options' header will be ignored only if it's present (which it isn't in this case). As it stands, this warning might lead some people on a wild goose chase trying to figure out what's going on with these headers."

steps to reproduce:

actual results:

the following unreported blocks accumulates steadily every time the file is posted to service worker.
------
unreported {
  18 blocks in heap block record 60 of 15,643
  73,728 bytes (73,728 requested / 0 slop)
  individual block sizes: 4,096 x 18
  0.06% of the heap (28.91% cumulative)
  0.15% of unreported (76.41% cumulative)
  allocated at {

    #02: mozilla::dmd::alloccallback(void*, unsigned long, mozilla::dmd::thread*) (/mnt/md0/gecko-dev/memory/replace/dmd/dmd.cpp:1024)
    #03: replace_malloc(unsigned long) (/mnt/md0/gecko-dev/memory/replace/dmd/dmd.cpp:1092)
    #04: nssegmentedbuffer::appendnewsegment() (/mnt/md0/gecko-dev/xpcom/io/nssegmentedbuffer.cpp:60)
    #05: nspipe::getwritesegment(char*&, unsigned int&) (/mnt/md0/gecko-dev/xpcom/io/nspipe3.cpp:822)
    #06: nspipeoutputstream::writesegments(nsresult (*)(nsioutputstream*, void*, char*, unsigned int, unsigned int, unsigned int*), void*, unsigned int, unsigned int*) (/mnt/md0/gecko-dev/xpcom/io/nspipe3.cpp:1665)

    #08: nsastreamcopier::process() (/mnt/md0/gecko-dev/xpcom/io/nsstreamutils.cpp:302)
  }
}
------

actually, there is a nspipe object whose refcnt remains 3, and therefore is never deleted.

the nspipe should be deleted, and no accumulated blocks on dmd dump.

Here's the rewritten bug report:

So, I'm trying to reproduce this weird behavior with Firefox, and it seems to happen on three different platforms: Windows 10, Linux Mint 20, and macOS 11.1. The versions of Firefox involved are beta 90.0b6 (build id: 20210610185818) and nightly 91.0a1 (build id: 20210610215038). 

To get to the issue, I need a few things set up first. I have to create a Normandy default type recipe that sets some preferences with non-default values - think of it like a special experiment mode for Firefox. For example, I'd set "browser.topsites.experiment.ebay-2020-1" to true. Then, I need a user.js file that enrolls me in this experiment. 

To reproduce the bug, I follow these steps: First, I head to "about:config" and create those same preferences with experiment values (like setting "browser.topsites.experiment.ebay-2020-1" to true). Then, I restart Firefox. Next, I go to the profile directory folder, copy that user.js file from before, and then restart Firefox again. After that, I head back to "about:studies", unenroll from the study, and restart Firefox one more time. Finally, I go back to "about:config" and check out those preferences.

What I expected to happen was that all my preferences set before enrolling in the experiment would still be there after I unenrolled - essentially, they'd keep their user value. But what actually happens is that if those preferences have the same values as the ones used by that branch, they get deleted after unenrollment.
