steps to reproduce:

this is a preliminary incident report. our investigation into this matter is ongoing. 

1. how your ca first became aware of the problem (e.g. via a problem report submitted to your problem reporting mechanism, a discussion in mozilla.dev.security.policy, a bugzilla bug, or internal self-audit), and the time and date. 

the issue was discovered by our validation team while performing a routine check of an ev tls order. 

2. a timeline of the actions your ca took in response. a timeline is a date-and-time-stamped sequence of all relevant events. this may include events before the incident was reported, such as when a particular requirement became applicable, or a document changed, or a bug was introduced, or an audit was done. 

- 2021-07-10t02:34:38-00:00 ev tls order reviewed and approved by one of our validation specialists. 
- 2021-07-12t03:38:36-00:00 customer care requests for an update on the abovementioned order. 
- 2021-07-12t09:15:41-00:00 the issuance of an ev tls certificate with serial number 776752935acf6697078d9cb5547921a6 is triggered with the invocation of an api call by one of our resellers. 
- 2021-07-13t16:05:00-00:00 in the process of performing 2p approval, one of our senior validation specialists determines that the certificate was issued without stored evidence of 2p approval in the system. the issue is reported by registering an internal ticket. 
- 2021-07-13t16:37:00-00:00 the ticket is processed with high priority by a senior software engineer. a bug is discovered in our api and a hotfix is immediately deployed. investigation continues to determine the population of the possibly affected certificates. 
- 2021-07-14t20:22:00-00:00 the population of possibly affected certificates is sought and determined to be eleven (11) ev tls certificates. 
- 2021-07-15t15:00:00-00:00 the issue is picked up by our security auditing department and investigation begins. 
- 2021-07-16t00:46:58-00:00 additional technical information is shared by the software engineers. 
- 2021-07-16t02:07:05-00:00 audit logs of the approvals of the abovementioned population are presented. security auditors initiate a detailed review to determine whether and for which exact certificates there is a lack of 2p approval evidence. 
- 2021-07-19t19:31:00-00:00 after detailed review of the abovementioned population by our security auditors and discussions with the validation team, two (2) additional problematic certificates are found. subsequent review confirms that validation evidence supported issuance for all three (3) affected certificates, however immediate revocation is requested due to the lack of 2p approval at the time of issuance. 
- 2021-07-19t21:56:00-00:00 all three (3) affected certificates revoked. 
- 2021-07-20t11:00:00-00:00 security auditors start gathering all the information and compiling a preliminary incident report. 
- 2021-07-23: filed initial bugzilla report. 

3. whether your ca has stopped, or has not yet stopped, issuing certificates with the problem. a statement that you have will be considered a pledge to the community; a statement that you have not requires an explanation. 

a hotfix was immediately deployed and tested after the issue was detected. no similar issuances can be performed currently. 

4. a summary of the problematic certificates. for each problem: number of certs, and the date the first and last certs with that problem were issued.  

three (3) ev tls certificates, issued between 2021-05-18 and 2021-07-12. 

5. the complete certificate data for the problematic certificates. the recommended way to provide this is to ensure each certificate is logged to ct and then list the fingerprints or crt.sh ids, either in the report or as an attached spreadsheet, with one list per distinct problem.  

impacted certificates (and their corresponding pre-certificates): 

s/n: 4f3ff4dc563aa9c46f18254998643ba6 (https://crt.sh/?id=4549278351) 
s/n: 45ba1526442ba72cc562493d99bcf757 (https://crt.sh/?id=4834857365) 
s/n: 776752935acf6697078d9cb5547921a6 (https://crt.sh/?id=4851729123) 

6. explanation about how and why the mistakes were made or bugs introduced, and how they avoided detection until now. 

the bug was introduced when the 2-person approval was migrated from the ca software to the ra portal on 2021-04-13. the purpose of this change was to allow full processing of validations in the ra portal by validation specialists.  

a faulty if check in the ra api code allowed issuance of ev tls certificates with a single person approval. the bug did not affect ev code signing or other types of certificates except ev tls . this issue also did not affect other validations performed via our ra portal; it was limited to our api, which is currently being used only by specific resellers for the issuance of a limited number of certificates. 

the bug passed undetected to the production systems despite the fact that the change was reviewed both within the development department (code review) and by the compliance department (change review). the issue was also not detected during our quarterly certificate reviews due to the low number of affected certificates. 

7. list of steps your ca is taking to resolve the situation and ensure such issuance will not be repeated in the future, accompanied with a timeline of when your ca expects to accomplish these things. 

immediate actions are described in steps 2-4 of this report and include the emergency deployment of the code fix to prevent further problematic issuances, the involvement of our internal auditing department, the thorough review of the possibly affected certificates and the revocation of the affected certificates after confirming the issue. 

initial review focuses on: 

- why the bug was introduced in the first place and in particular why it affected only ev tls certificates but not ev code signing, which follow the same 2p approval principle;
- how the issue was not detected during the code or compliance review, before reaching production.

our investigation is ongoing and analysis is being conducted to reveal any underlying weaknesses and, according to the results, decide any additional measures and improvements in our systems and processes, so that such occurrences are not repeated in the future. 

a full incident report shall be filed here when our investigation is complete. in the meantime, we will post regular updates.
user_behviou: Good
NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

So, here's what happened: our validation team discovered an issue with some EV TLS orders while doing a routine check. It turns out that between July 10 and July 12, we issued three EV TLS certificates without proper two-person approval. This was all due to a bug in our API code that allowed single-person approval for these types of certificates.

Here's what happened timeline-wise:

* On July 10, one of our validation specialists reviewed and approved an EV TLS order.
* On July 12, customer care asked us to update on the status of this order. Meanwhile, one of our resellers triggered the issuance of another EV TLS certificate.
* Later that day, a senior validation specialist noticed that the certificate was issued without stored evidence of two-person approval. We opened an internal ticket and started investigating.

We quickly deployed a hotfix to prevent further issuances with this problem. Our software engineers worked on fixing the bug, and we began reviewing all possibly affected certificates.

As it turned out, 11 EV TLS certificates were potentially impacted. We found that two more certificates had issues after doing a detailed review. We immediately revoked all three problematic certificates.

Here are some key details about these certificates:

* Three EV TLS certificates were issued between May 18 and July 12.
* The first certificate was issued on May 18, while the last one was issued on July 12.

As for how this mistake happened, it was due to a faulty IF check in our RA API code. This change was made back on April 13 to allow full processing of validations in the RA portal by validation specialists. The bug didn't affect EV code signing or other types of certificates except for EV TLS. It also didn't impact other validations performed via our RA portal.

The good news is that we've already taken steps to resolve this situation, including deploying the code fix, reviewing the possibly affected certificates, and revoking the problematic ones.

Looking ahead, we're focusing on understanding why this bug was introduced in the first place and how it went undetected during our regular code and compliance reviews. We'll use these findings to make sure such issues don't happen again in the future. Our investigation is ongoing, but I'll keep you posted with any updates!

2. close the app and open it again with the telemetry command (e.g for firefox beta.: adb shell am start -n org.mozilla.firefox_beta/mozilla.telemetry.glean.debug.gleandebugactivity --ez logpings true --es sendping metrics --es debugviewtag <name>).
3. navigate to the nimbus experiments menu and verify the experiment’s branch checkmark.
4. navigate to the glean viewer (https://debug-ping-preview.firebaseapp.com/pings/<name>) and search the “message-malformed” ping through the events received.

**[expected result]:**
 - the client is enrolled in the malformed experiment and the “message-malformed” event is displayed in the glean viewer.

**[actual result]:**
- the client is enrolled in the malformed experiment and the “message-malformed” event is not displayed in the glean viewer.


**[notes]:**
- the issue is reproducible both when “text” is not set, and when “text”:”” is set. whether “style”:”notification” is set does not affect the result.
- attaching a screen recording of the issue [here](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1sknckjfbg1sxwar73eqzbbzltejmnftc/view?usp=sharing).

NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

I created an attachment to go along with this issue - [attachment 9247491](2021-10-25-thunderbird-calendar-event.jpg). It's weird, because I'm seeing some strange behavior when working with calendar events in Thunderbird. Here's what's happening: when I load the Add-ons panel and get a tab (using `messenger.tabs.query`) and an active message (`messenger.messagedisplay.getdisplayedmessage`), everything looks normal. But then, if I drill down to get the full data of the message using `messenger.messages.getfull(message.id)`, things start to go awry.

What's happening is that when I cycle through the parts array and try to show each part on the console (`console.log(onepart)`), I can see the structure of the parts (content type, headers, name, size, etc.), but sometimes the "body" element is missing - and it only happens when the content type is "text/calendar". What's even weirder is that there are error messages in the log saying something about not finding a file (FLE) - which seems related to timezone abbreviations used by Google Calendar and Microsoft Outlook.

In some cases, if the message has a name set by the sender, I can use `messenger.messages.listattachments` to get the body of the calendar event. But in other cases, I have to resort to using `messenger.messages.getraw` and splitting it by boundaries to get the body - which is super wonky.

According to the documentation (https://webextension-api.thunderbird.net/en/91/messages.html#messages-messagepart), I'm expecting this structure to include a "body" element, which seems like it should be there for innermost parts. Instead, it's just missing.

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (x11; ubuntu; linux x86_64; rv:122.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/122.0

steps to reproduce:

using the following codepen: https://codepen.io/matuzo/pen/ylwynyy?editors=1010

1. open the devtools
2. inspect the button inside the <some-bugs>
3. click the locator/ "select element #h1" button in the inspector tree view


actual results:

you jump to the element with id #h1 outside of the <some-bugs> webcomponent. 

this is incorrect because aria-labelledby can not cross a webcomponent boundary, so the "h1" needs to exist inside the webcomponent to be able to be referenced.


expected results:

the linked element can not be found in the same root, so the button to select it should work similarly to when a completely non-existant id is referenced.

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report in a conversational tone:

"I'm running into an issue with CodePen and Firefox (version 122.0). I was experimenting with some code and noticed that when I try to jump to an element with ID #h1 using the DevTools, it takes me outside of the web component where the <some-bugs> element is defined. This isn't right because aria-labelledby attributes can't cross boundaries like this - they need to reference elements within the same scope. In other words, I should only be able to select elements that exist within the same root as the <some-bugs> element. Instead, if an ID like #h1 doesn't exist within the web component, the button should simply not find a match and give me a "not found" error instead of trying to jump to something outside of its scope."

text:
created attachment 9288717
ffdesyncsecure.js

steps to reproduce:

i am reporting a desynchronization issue between document.cookie and the actual content of the cookie jar in firefox. this report follows https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1782561, but i think these are two separate issues. similarly to the previous report, this inconsistency could introduce vulnerabilities in applications trusting the cookies read from document.cookie. in particular, this issue may allow same-site and network attackers to spoof the value of a cookie previously set as secure.

1. visit https://example.com
2. set a secure cookie using the console, e.g., document.cookie = "test=secure; secure"
3. in the same tab, visit http://example.com
4. set an insecure cookie `test` to the value `insecure`: document.cookie = "test=insecure"
5. force a refresh to http://example.com

a demo is available at https://ffdesyncsecure.minimal.blue/. nodejs sources are attached to this report. 


actual results:

step 4. sets the cookie `test=insecure` in document.cookie, altough a secure cookie with the same name (`test`) already exists. notice that the cookie `test=insecure` is not saved in the cookie jar by inspecting devtools storage -> cookies.
step 5. as expected, the `test` cookie is not attached in the request to http://example.com. at the same time, document.cookie still shows `test=insecure`.

the current behavior causes a desynchronization between document.cookie and the actual cookie jar of the browser.



expected results:

the document.cookie setter at step 4. should silently fail to set the cookie `test=insecure` due to the presence of a secure cookie with the same name. chromium-based browsers behave as expected, i.e., the cookie `test=insecure` does not populate document.cookie.
user_behviou:
I'd rate this bug report as "good". Here's why:

1. **Steps to Reproduce (S2R)**: The steps are detailed and easy to follow.
2. **Expected Result (ER)**: A clear description of what should happen is provided.
3. **Actual Result (AR)**: A thorough explanation of the actual behavior is given, including relevant screenshots or observations.

The report lacks some minor details:

* No information about the environment or build number.
* The "Additional Information" section is mostly empty, except for a mention of NodeJS sources and an attachment.

Overall, this bug report effectively communicates the issue, its potential impact, and provides clear steps to reproduce.
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report in a conversational tone:

I'm reporting an issue where Firefox desynchronizes between what's shown in `document.cookie` and what's actually stored in the cookie jar. This is similar to another bug I reported, but I think they're two separate problems. The problem is that this inconsistency could lead to vulnerabilities in apps that trust the cookies read from `document.cookie`, especially since it might allow same-site or network attackers to spoof a secure cookie.

To reproduce the issue, follow these steps: visit https://example.com, set a secure cookie using the console (like `document.cookie = "test=secure; secure"`), then in the same tab, visit http://example.com and set an insecure cookie called "test" with the value "insecure". Next, force a refresh to http://example.com. A demo is available at https://ffdesyncsecure.minimal.blue/, and I've attached the NodeJS sources to this report.

What happens is that step 4 sets the cookie `test=insecure` in `document.cookie`, but it doesn't actually get saved in the cookie jar (as you can see by inspecting DevTools Storage -> Cookies). Then, when you visit http://example.com again, the `test` cookie isn't sent with the request, but `document.cookie` still shows that it's set to "insecure". This means there's a desynchronization between what's shown in `document.cookie` and what's actually stored in the browser.

The expected behavior is that step 4 should silently fail to set the cookie `test=insecure` because there's already a secure cookie with the same name. Chrome-based browsers do this correctly, so it seems like Firefox has an issue here.

So, I'm seeing some issues with the permissions panel in Firefox when I go to Reddit and click on the shield icon. It's happening on my Windows 10 machine, but also on my Mac (running macOS 10.15) and Ubuntu (18.04 x64). To reproduce this, just launch Firefox, head over to Reddit, click that shield icon in the URL bar, and then inspect the protection panel. 

What I'm expecting to see is a slightly bigger radio button width, an underlined "site not working?" link, and all those section headers written in lowercase (like "protection settings" or "tracking content"). The Figma specs should be followed here. And, of course, there should be some borders separating each section, with just a few pixels left at the edges - that's what I'm expecting to see.

But what I actually get is radio icons that are smaller than they should be, no underline on that "site not working?" link, and those section headers in uppercase instead of lowercase. And worst of all, those borders stretch all the way across the panel, which isn't right - it should leave some space at each side like the first border below the protection for a website does get it right.

I'm giving this bug a severity level of S2 because the permissions panel isn't fully styled for Proton yet. And just to confirm, I don't think this is a regression issue since it's been happening all along. 

Oh, and by the way, if you want to see what I mean, just take a look at the attached screenshots!

text:
user agent: mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 10.0; win64; x64) applewebkit/537.36 (khtml, like gecko) chrome/91.0.4472.124 safari/537.36

steps to reproduce:

### microsec incident report - misissuance of 1 ov certificate with key usage keyencipherment

---

> i -- how your ca first became aware of the problem (e.g. via a problem report submitted to your problem reporting mechanism, a discussion in mozilla.dev.security.policy, a bugzilla bug, or internal self-audit), and the time and date.

microsec received an email based incident report to info@e-szigno.hu at tuesday, august 31, 2021 9:36 am

---

> ii -- a timeline of the actions your ca took in response. a timeline is a date-and-time-stamped sequence of all relevant events. this may include events before the incident was reported, such as when a particular requirement became applicable, or a document changed, or a bug was introduced, or an audit was done.

###### 2021-08-31 07:36 utc

- receive a notification email about the incorrectly issued tls certificate

###### 2021-08-31 08:27 utc

- microsec customer service officer processed the incoming email and opened an internal bug

###### 2021-08-31 08:42 utc

- initiating an investigation to identify the cause(s) of the error and to prevent further similar errors

###### 2021-08-31 09:54 utc

- contacting the site owner and informing them about the planned revocation

###### 2021-08-31 10:12 utc

- revocation of the incorrect certificate

---

> iii -- whether your ca has stopped, or has not yet stopped, issuing certificates with the problem. a statement that you have will be considered a pledge to the community; a statement that you have not requires an explanation.


the quick investigation confirmed that the current policy documents and certificate profiles are ok and that there is no need to suspend the certificate issuance.

---

> iv -- a summary of the problematic certificates. for each problem: number of certs, and the date the first and last certs with that problem were issued.

###### 2020-03-09

- one ov certificate with ecc key was issued with an incorrent key usage bit setting

---

> v -- the complete certificate data for the problematic certificates. the recommended way to provide this is to ensure each certificate is logged to ct and then list the fingerprints or crt.sh ids, either in the report or as an attached spreadsheet, with one list per distinct problem.

| domain | crt.sh link |
| --- | --- |
| v2x-pki.com | https://crt.sh/?id=2730469679 |

---

> vi -- explanation about how and why the mistakes were made or bugs introduced, and how they avoided detection until now.

#### we performed the initial investigation and we found the following

###### 2018-04-21
- microsec installed an automatic check in the ca software which limits the usability of the different certificate profiles according to the type of the public key in the enduser certificate. the operation is based on a configuration file, which lists the allowed certificate profiles for a given key type in a given ica.

###### 2020-03-05
- version 2.13 of our public policies was released. this included the correct requirement for ku bits in case of ecc key.
- certificate profiles were updated according to the cp change to use version 2.13 cp oid values. certificate profiles included the appropriate ku setting for ecc based certificates.

###### 2020-03-09
- the ov certificate was issued under our rsa based ica "e-szigno ssl ca 2014", but for an ecc end-entity key.  microsec does not usually mix different key types, it was an exception event that we have issued a certificate for en ecc key from an rsa based ca hierarchy.
- the ro officer issued the certificate using the default rsa certificate profile
- the ca allowed the issuance of the certificate for the ecc key with an rsa certificate profile due to a configuration problem
- the certificate became faulty because an improper certificate profile was used for issuance, which resulted the incorrect ku setting
- the manual immediate post issuance quality control check did not recognize the fault


###### 2021-01-07
- microsec introduced the automatic cablint and zlint checks for each tls certificates which replaced the former manual checks.

###### 2020-2021
- microsec developed its certificate policy management system in two steps during 2020 and 2021. it results higher accountability and minimize the risk of misissuance.


#### summary of the findings

the misissuance was caused by a configuration problem in the certificate profile management system 
- ro officer selected the standard rsa based certificate profile for the ecc key in the rsa based ca (it is not her/his task to check the key type)
- the rsa based certificate profile was allowed for ecc keys in the rsa based ca due to a configuration problem (configuration fault)
- the certificate was issued with improper ku bits
- the manual immediate post issuance quality control check did not identify the problem
- the following quarterly quality control check did not select this specific certificate to re-check in april 2020

---

> vii -- list of steps your ca is taking to resolve the situation and ensure such issuance will not be repeated in the future, accompanied with a timeline of when your ca expects to accomplish these things.

#### immediate actions

- microsec revoked the affected ov tls certificate within 3 hours.
- microsec has verified all active certificate profiles, they were ok at the time of misissuance, and they are still ok.
- microsec has verified all active policy documents, they were ok at the time of misissuance and they are still ok.
- a quick initial investigation was made to find out the reason of the misissuance.
- microsec identified the causes of the misissuance as you see it above.
- microsec has verified the configuration of the certificate profiles in the ca software, it is ok.
- microsec checked all the valid certificates for this type of problem, there is no more certificate with this problem.
- microsec opened an incident bug in mozilla's bugzilla with the present report.


#### further planned actions

##### deadline: 2021-09-15

- microsec will check wether the present controls are sufficient to prevent a misissuance with this problem again.
- microsec will keep a training for the ro operators how to use the proper certificate profiles according to the type of the enduser key.

---
user_behviou: Best
NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten paragraph in a natural, conversational tone:

So here's what happened: we got an email on August 31st saying that one of our certificates was issued incorrectly. Our team jumped into action and started investigating right away. By 8:27 UTC, we had opened an internal bug to track the issue and were working to figure out what went wrong. We ended up contacting the site owner and letting them know about the planned revocation, which happened at 10:12 UTC. After our quick investigation, we confirmed that there was no need to suspend certificate issuance because everything else was good - just this one mistake.

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

I'm experiencing an issue with Firefox on my Windows 10 machine, but it also happens on Mac and Ubuntu - I'll list those platforms too. When I try to download multiple files at once from thinkbroadband.com, only one of them gets downloaded or removed as expected. The problem is that the "allow/remove" option in the download panel doesn't work correctly when there are mixed content downloads. Here's what happens: if you select two files to download and then click on the first one in the download panel, everything works fine - it either starts downloading or gets removed. But if you try to do the same with the second file (or any subsequent ones), Firefox just ignores your selection and tries to allow/remove the first file instead, which is already being processed or has finished. This means that the "allow/remove" option only works once, after which it's broken until I restart my browser.

we'll use this bug to fix bug 1727995 properly.


+++ this bug was initially created as a clone of bug #1727995 +++

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (x11; ubuntu; linux x86_64; rv:91.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/91.0

steps to reproduce:

see attached zip file for small sample.

the "websocket.js" file will need to be modified. a server that accepts a websocket request should be configured in the "server_uri" variable. providing a working websocket server is a little complex and is out of scope for this request. it can be done with various python bits.

once "websocket.js" has been updated you can serve the folder via `python -m http.server` and navigate to localhost.

click on either of the buttons on the web page in order to create a websocket connection, load some binary data (via some random files i found on my computer), and send it over the socket.


actual results:

when trying to send a blob that is over 500 kilobytes firefox hangs and never sends the data. if the blob is smaller the data is sent right away.


expected results:

data should be sent. websocket supports like gigabytes, right?

---

i tried using mozregression to figure out if this broke at some point, but i ended up with a reggression back in like 2018.. which is weird and i don't know if it's helpful.

last known good: 2018-11-06
first known bad: 2018-11-07
pushlog: https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/pushloghtml?fromchange=6e842238034cd847ede178b4e65ea07704e4ffe6&tochange=5836a60614764631436bf5030c5baa34c676c7a2

mozregression couldn't find builds to get a smaller range. as this was almost three years ago i feel like it may be irrelevant, and i find it surprising nobody has noticed a 500k limit on websocket over this time.

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

Hey there, I'm trying to fix another issue that's related to bug #1727995 (yeah, it's a clone of that one!). So, when I try to send big files (think bigger than 500KB) via WebSockets in Firefox, the browser just hangs and never sends the data. It works fine if the file is smaller though - weird, right? 

To reproduce this issue, you'll need to modify a script called "websocket.js" and set up a test server that accepts WebSocket requests (don't worry, it's not too hard to do with some Python bits). Then, just serve the folder using `python -m http.server` and visit localhost in your browser. Click on either of the buttons to create a WebSocket connection, load some binary data from a sample file I've attached, and send it over the socket. That's when you'll see Firefox hang if the file is too big.

According to my testing, this issue has been around since 2018 (yeah, that's weird - I'd have thought someone would have noticed by now!). The last good build was on November 6th, and the first bad one was on November 7th. If you want to take a look at the pushlog for more details, it's available here: https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/pushloghtml?fromchange=6e842238034cd847ede178b4e65ea07704e4ffe6&tochange=5836a60614764631436bf5030c5baa34c676c7a2.

logcat.txt

### preconditions
1. set a fingerprint signature to your device.
2. in focus --> settings --> privacy & security --> switching apps --> enable the "use fingerprint to unlock app". 

### steps to reproduce
1. long-tap on the homescreen of the device.
2. select to add the focus widget.
3. tap on the microphone icon from the widget.
4. after using the fingerprint to unlock the app, observe the results of the search.
6. repeat steps 3 or 4 several times and observe the number of the opened tabs.

### expected behavior
each search results in a new tab, the number of tabs increases.
the voice search works as expected.

### actual results
only the first voice search via the widget is correctly working.
the second voice search is not working anymore. 
the results from the first search made are displayed, the number of opened tabs is not increased.
it is working as expected when the "use fingerprint" option is disabled.

### details
* tested on google pixel 6 (android 15)
* tested on focus nightly 134.0a1 from 11/6, and on beta 133.0b4
* not reproducible on samsung galaxy tab s9 ultra (android 14), google pixel 9 (android 14)

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report in a conversational tone:

"I'm experiencing some weird behavior with the Focus widget on my Google Pixel 6 device running Android 15. So, I have fingerprint unlock enabled for apps and I've set up the "Use fingerprint to unlock app" option in Settings > Privacy & Security > Switching apps. When I add the Focus widget to my home screen, select the microphone icon, and use my fingerprint to unlock the app, everything seems fine - it does a search and opens a new tab with the results. But here's the thing: after the first time, any subsequent searches via the widget just don't work anymore! The same results from the first search keep showing up, but no new tabs are opened. It's like the voice search functionality gets stuck or something. What's even weirder is that if I disable the "Use fingerprint to unlock app" option, everything works as expected - each search opens a new tab and the voice search still functions normally. I've tried this on both Focus Nightly 134.0a1 and Beta 133.0b4, but it only happens on my Pixel 6 (Android 15). It's not reproducible on my Samsung Galaxy Tab S9 Ultra (Android 14) or Google Pixel 9 (Android 14), so maybe it's a specific issue with this device or Android version?"

wiki search.mp4

### preconditions
1. perform at least a temporary search with the wikipedia and youtube topic-specific search engines and create some bookmarks. (to add youtube to the search engine list go to settings > search > + add search engine > select youtube and tap on the check mark in the right upper corner). 
2. go to settings > search engine. make sure that the "search bookmarks" option is enabled.

### steps to reproduce
1. tap on the dropdown menu from the google search engine icon. 
2. select the wikipedia topic-specific search engine.
3. type in a valid search term (related to the saved bookmarks previously created with the wikipedia search engine).
4. observe if search suggestions are displayed.
5. repeat steps 2-4 with the youtube topic-specific search engine selected. 

### expected behavior
temporary selected topic-specific search engines (amazon.com, ebay, wikipedia, reddit, youtube)  should display suggestions from the previously bookmarked searches made with the same search engine.

### actual behavior
temporary selected wikipedia and youtube topic-specific search engines do not display suggestions from the previously bookmarked searches made with the same search engine. 

### device information

* firefox version: nightly 114.0a1 from 05/03
* android device model: lenovo yoga tab 11,  google pixel 7
* android os version: android 11, android 13

### any additional information?
- when searching for bookmarks in settings > bookmarks menu, the expected search results are displayed. 

- if the user is signed in with the same firefox account on multiple devices (e.g. mobile and desktop) and wikipedia and youtube bookmarks are created on desktop, they will be displayed as bookmarks suggestions in step 4, while the bookmarks created on the mobile device will still not be displayed.

"I've got a weird issue with the search functionality in Firefox. So, I set up some bookmarks using the Wikipedia and YouTube topic-specific search engines, and everything seems to work fine - my bookmarks show up when I search for them in the settings menu. But then, I go to perform a temporary search within those same bookmarked topics, and that's where things get wonky. When I select either the Wikipedia or YouTube search engine from the dropdown menu, I'd expect some suggestions based on my previous searches to pop up. However, nothing shows up! It's like Firefox has completely forgotten about all those bookmarks I saved earlier. I've tried this on both my Lenovo Yoga Tab 11 and Google Pixel 7 devices, running Android 11 and 13 respectively, and the issue persists across multiple browsers (I'm using Nightly 114.0a1). The only weird exception is when I sign in to Firefox on multiple devices - if I create bookmarks on my desktop, they magically show up as suggestions on my mobile device, but not the other way around. Any ideas what's going on here?"

text:
user agent: mozilla/5.0 (windows nt 10.0; win64; x64; rv:89.0) gecko/20100101 firefox/89.0

steps to reproduce:

- open a context menu that has disabled menuitems. i.e. right click on a video player on youtube
- use arrow keys to advance/rewind "focus"


actual results:

- disabled menuitems can still gain `_moz-menuactive` attribute, even though there is no visual feedback to show that they are focused or hovered
- that is, the css rules that style the active menuitems explicitly say `:not([disabled="true"])`, or they have some overriding rule like `[_moz-menuactive="true"][disabled="true"] {color: graytext;  background-color: unset;}`, so you can't tell whether a disabled button is "active" (in this case meaning keyboard-focused or cursor-hovered)
- from a sighted user's point of view, it looks like you're advancing down the list, then all of a sudden the cursor showing the selected menu/menuitem just abruptly disappears, before reappearing when you navigate to the next non-disabled element in the list.


expected results:

- those rules are clearly intended to prevent visual feedback that would mislead a sighted user into thinking the element is an active affordance.
- but the functions that advance through menuitems do not abide by the same philosophy. this could mislead a blind or visually impaired user depending on their screen reader settings, but presumably it's also visually confusing and annoying for sighted users, (at least for me) since an element that can't be activated or interacted with in any way is being pseudo-focused, so it's consuming keyboard inputs. and meanwhile, there's no visual indication that it's holding focus except for the absence of highlighting on any other menuitems in the list.
- there's a [bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=14841) from 2 decades ago making the opposite argument. i know there are differing opinions on this, since the existence of the disabled button should still be apparent to screen readers. but there are ways to make disabled buttons visible to screen readers and still let the keyboard navigation walker skip them. look at the customizable toolbar buttons for example.
- looking at the most modern parts of firefox, i can't find any examples of focus behaving like the context menus do. but i can find a ton of counterexamples, like [browser-toolbarkeynav.js](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/browser/base/content/browser-toolbarkeynav.js#65), [panelmultiview.jsm](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/browser/components/customizableui/panelmultiview.jsm#1594), even [the basic button element](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/toolkit/content/widgets/button.js#189).
- also, making disabled buttons known to screen readers is not the be-all, end-all, since the buttons do not provide any information as to why they are disabled. even with vision, the most a user can glean from their existence is the fact that they could conceivably provide the named functionality in some other, unknown circumstance.
- i still think that's valuable information so i wouldn't want them hidden, either visually or to screen readers, but i think the priority of visibility should be lower than that of avoiding the confusion caused by permitting disabled elements to be focused, especially when there's no visual feedback. ideally, they should be read by screen readers but not focusable at all, just like toolbar buttons with open popups. to that end, context menus could use the same kind of node filter setup that the javascript key navigation modules use.
user_behviou:
I would rate this bug report as "good". Here's why:

1. Steps to Reproduce (S2R): Present and detailed.
2. Expected Result (ER): Clear and well-articulated.
3. Actual Result (AR): Well-explained, with specific examples and observations.

The only missing element is Additional Information, which would provide useful context about the environment, software version, or build number where this issue was encountered. However, since you provided a user agent string, it's clear that you did have some relevant information available.

Overall, the report is well-written, easy to follow, and provides a clear explanation of the issue, making it "good".
NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

"I was testing Firefox with my keyboard and noticed some weird behavior when navigating through disabled menu items in a context menu. For instance, if I right-click on a YouTube video player and then use the arrow keys to advance or rewind, I can still select disabled menu items even though there's no visual feedback indicating that they're focused or hovered. This is problematic because those menu items have CSS rules that style them differently when they're active, but since they're disabled, it looks like nothing's happening - and that's confusing.

"As someone who's familiar with screen readers, I can imagine how this could be even more frustrating for visually impaired users. The problem is that the functions that advance through menu items don't respect the same philosophy as the CSS rules intended to prevent visual feedback from misleading sighted users. This means that a disabled menu item can still 'hold focus' and consume keyboard inputs, making it seem like it's an active affordance - even though it's not.

"I know there are differing opinions on this, but I think we should prioritize avoiding confusion caused by focusing disabled elements over making them visible to screen readers. There are ways to do both, actually - take a look at how customizable toolbar buttons work, for instance. And while it's true that we can make disabled buttons known to screen readers, that's not the only consideration here.

"What I think would be ideal is if context menus could use the same kind of node filter setup as some of the JavaScript key navigation modules do - this would prevent disabled menu items from being focused at all. That way, we'd avoid confusing users and ensure a better overall experience."

NEW_llama_output:
Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a natural, conversational tone:

I'm experiencing an issue with my Bluetooth microphone in Firefox 91.0. Specifically, it stopped working properly during web meetings or calls using software like 3cx and Webex. I've tried granting temporary or permanent access to the mic, but it doesn't make a difference - it just doesn't work.

The weird thing is that this issue only started happening after I upgraded from Firefox 90.0.2 to 91.0. I've tried downgrading back to 90.0.2 and the microphone works fine again. So, it seems like something in the 91.0 update broke my Bluetooth mic.

Here are the steps to reproduce the issue:

* Start with a clean install of Firefox 90.0.2 (no extensions installed, new profile)
* Connect my Sony WH-XB900N headset
* Go to a web-meeting site and grant access to the microphone
* Make a call - speaker works fine, but the mic is not picking up any audio

Then, I updated to Firefox 91.0:

* Rebooted my computer
* Connected my headset again
* Went to a web-meeting site and granted access to the microphone
* Made a call again - speaker still works, but the mic is now muted!

After downgrading back to 90.0.2, everything worked fine again.

The MozRegression log shows some details about the changeset that caused this issue:

* The commit message mentions adding an utility function in audiosegment to append interleaved buffer data
* It seems like something changed around this point that broke my Bluetooth mic

Expected result: my Bluetooth microphone should still work properly after upgrading from Firefox 90.0.2 to 91.0.

Here's the rewritten bug report:

Hey, so I wanted to file this bug report about an issue I found in Firefox beta 112.0b5, but it also affects the nightly builds (112.0a1). Luckily, the release and ESR versions are fine. The problem happens on Windows 10, macOS 12, and Ubuntu 22.04.

To reproduce it, you need to create a new profile in Firefox, then go to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9nf0k2nj7n8 and hover over the first-time toggle for the pip (that's the little icon that lets you expand or collapse the video player). What should happen is that your cursor should change to the "hand" icon when you're hovering over the whole expanded toggle. But what actually happens is that the cursor doesn't change at all - specifically, it doesn't change on the upper-left part of the pip toggle.

I'll be looking into figuring out which specific changes caused this issue (that's called a "regression range"), but I wanted to get the bug report filed ASAP so we can start working on fixing it!

user agent: mozilla/5.0 (macintosh; intel mac os x 10_15_7) applewebkit/537.36 (khtml, like gecko) chrome/121.0.0.0 safari/537.36

steps to reproduce:

1. go to https://jsfiddle.net/3js69ngu/3/. you will find a custom web component imitating a checkbox form control.
2. click on "submit form" in the "custom checkbox" section



actual results:

- no validation message appears
- console error: "an invalid form control is not focusable."

there is the "setvalidity(flags?: validitystateflags, message?: string, anchor?: htmlelement): void;" method to set the validity state of a custom component using elementinternals. as per description, the "anchor" parameter, which is used as the anchor to display the validity message, is optional. however, in firefox, the message is not displayed as long anchor parameter is not provided. the error message "an invalid form control is not focusable." is not true, as the custom form component (see https://jsfiddle.net/3js69ngu/3/) is focusable. providing the host of the component as parameter is not possible, as the anchor parameter element needs to be inside the shadow dom.

definition:
anchor – an htmlelement which can be used by the user agent to report problems with this form submission.


expected results:

not passing an anchor should focus the host and display the message there. check chromium, where it is implemented and working like expected.

Here's a rewritten version of the bug report in a conversational tone:

"I'm running into some issues when trying to validate a custom web component that mimics a checkbox form control. I've created a simple fiddle at https://jsfiddle.net/3js69ngu/3/, and if you go there, click on the "Submit Form" button in the "Custom Checkbox" section, you'll see what's going on. What happens is that no validation message shows up, and in the console, I get an error saying "an invalid form control is not focusable." But here's the thing - the custom component is definitely focusable! The problem seems to be that Firefox isn't displaying the validation message unless I provide an anchor element, which doesn't make sense. According to the documentation, the anchor parameter should only be required if you want to display the error message somewhere specific. In this case, since the custom form component has its own host and is focusable, it seems like Firefox should just display the message there instead of complaining about not being focusable. Chrome gets this right, by the way - when I test it in Chromium, everything works as expected."

To reproduce this issue, I just followed these steps: opened the browser, clicked on the 'hamburger menu', chose settings, went to the privacy & security panel, checked the box for using a primary password, and then right-clicked on that 'Enter New Password' field. What should have happened is that the pop-up panel would display all the options correctly - but instead, it showed some blank ones. And get this - even when I tried to re-enter my password or view my current password (with 'use a primary password' unchecked), the same thing happened! So yeah, that's the issue I'm reporting - just thought you'd want to know."

**steps to reproduce**

 1. run firefox nightly on a linux laptop, with either `moz_enable_wayland=1` in a wayland session, ~~or with `moz_use_xinput2=1` in an x11 session~~
    * **edit: the bug only reproduces on wayland, not x11**
 2. set `apz.overscroll.enabled` to `true` in `about:config`
 3. load any page that's vertically scrollable
 4. overscroll the page at the top using the touchpad
 5. lift fingers from the touchpad while page is overscrolled and not moving, such that there isn't any velocity to trigger momentum scrolling

**expected results**

a snap-back animation is triggered to relieve the overscroll.

**actual results**

the page is stuck in the overscrolled state until you manually relieve the overscroll by scrolling in the opposite direction.

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

So, I've been noticing this weird issue with Firefox Nightly on my Linux laptop running Wayland (I tried it on X11 too, but it doesn't happen there). To reproduce it, you need to do a few things: first, make sure you're running Firefox Nightly and have the `moz_enable_wayland=1` flag enabled in your Wayland session. Then, head into `about:config` and set `apz.overscroll.enabled` to `true`. Next, load up any webpage that's got a lot of vertical scrolling goodness going on. Now, use your touchpad to overscroll the page all the way up (you know, like when you accidentally scroll past the top and it won't stop). The important part is that once you're fully overscrolled, lift your fingers off the touchpad without actually moving or triggering any momentum scrolling. What should happen next is that Firefox kicks in with a snap-back animation to get things back on track. But what actually happens is... nothing. The page just stays stuck in the overscrolled state until you manually scroll back down to relieve it.

5. click on "go back" from the toolbar to get to the page from step 2

- the file stops playing

**actual result**
- the file still plays in the background and the only way to stop it is to close the tab

**regression range**

**additional notes**
- the issue can be seen in the attachment.
- sometimes the playback will stop but when going forward to the "next page" again, the song will continue where it stopped and won't reset itself to 0:00.

NEW_llama_output:
Here's the rewritten bug report:

So, I've been noticing this weird issue in Firefox - when I download an MP3 file and it autoplays in a new tab, clicking the "go back" button doesn't stop the playback like I'd expect. Instead, the song just keeps playing in the background, and the only way to get rid of it is to close the whole tab. This happens in Firefox 92.0b8 and 93.0a1 on my Windows 11 machine.

To reproduce this issue, I launch Firefox, head to a specific page that has MP3 files available for download (like [this one](https://file-examples.com/index.php/sample-audio-files/sample-mp3-download/)), click "download" for any of the MP3 files, and then the file autoplays in a new tab. From there, I just click "go back" to get back to the original page. What should happen is that the playback stops, but instead it keeps going on and on.

I've also noticed some additional quirks - sometimes when I navigate away from the MP3 file or come back to it later, the playback will stop where it left off, rather than resetting to the start of the song. And weirdly, sometimes when I launch Firefox with the same profile and go straight to that page, the MP3 will automatically start playing without me even asking for it! I couldn't reproduce this initial issue on normal builds, but I did notice the playback continuing where it left off in some cases.

I've attached a video (attachment 9237944 - mp3 playback still going.gif) that shows what's happening, just in case you want to take a look.

So I noticed a weird issue with Firefox's about:downloads page on Windows 10 and Ubuntu 20. When you launch Firefox, download some test files, and then go to about:downloads, everything looks normal at first. But when you press the tab key or click on any of the listed downloads, the highlighted effect gets applied to the elements as expected.
